results.summary: Two Big Issue sellers who were stabbed to death in front of shoppers in Birmingham were probably known to their attacker, police say.
results.body: <body xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/a72f56d0-9092-6846-a81d-9c01abe18e14"><image id="65251617"/><paragraph role="introduction">Two Big Issue sellers who were stabbed to death in front of shoppers in Birmingham were probably known to their attacker, police have said.</paragraph><paragraph>Wayne Busst, 32, and Ian Gladwish, 31, both from Birmingham, were stabbed in Union Street at about 17:50 GMT on Friday. </paragraph><paragraph>Police said they had so far received a "fantastic response" from the public.</paragraph><paragraph>Earlier officers were granted more time to question a 23-year-old man who was arrested minutes after the stabbings.</paragraph><paragraph>West Midlands Police now has until 21:00 GMT to either charge or release the man, who was arrested near to the Odeon cinema in New Street.</paragraph><crosshead>'Utterly senseless'</crosshead><paragraph>The force said hundreds of people may have witnessed the stabbings, which happened during rush hour in one of the city's busiest areas.</paragraph><paragraph>Det Insp Buck Rogers, who is leading the investigation into the deaths, said early enquiries suggested they had not been "random" attacks.</paragraph><paragraph>He added: "The attacker appears to have known his victims."</paragraph><paragraph>He urged anyone else with information to contact police.</paragraph><paragraph>Big Issue founder and editor-in-chief John Bird has paid tribute to the two vendors and said everyone at the magazine was "absolutely devastated".</paragraph><paragraph>He said: "We are struggling to make any sense of this utterly senseless attack and our sincerest condolences go out to the families of the victims."</paragraph></body>
results.shortFormBody: <shortFormBody xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/a72f56d0-9092-6846-a81d-9c01abe18e14"><paragraph>Two Big Issue sellers who were stabbed to death in front of shoppers in Birmingham were probably known to their attacker, police have said.</paragraph><paragraph>Wayne Busst, 32, and Ian Gladwish, 31, both from Birmingham, were stabbed in Union Street at about 17:50 GMT on Friday.</paragraph><paragraph>Police said they had so far received a "fantastic response" from the public.</paragraph><paragraph>Earlier officers were granted more time to question a 23-year-old man who was arrested minutes after the stabbings.</paragraph></shortFormBody>

65238044.caption: West Midlands Police have cordoned off part of Martineau Place and Union Street

65250765.caption: Union Street was cordoned off on Friday night
65250765.altText: Union Street closed on Friday night

65241081.caption: Supt Richard Moore said it was important not "to jump to conclusions"

65241510.caption: Extra police patrols were put on in the city centre over the weekend
65241510.altText: The front of Sainsbury's in Union Street on Saturday morning

65251617.caption: Wayne Busst and Ian Gladwish were Big Issue sellers
65251617.altText: Wayne Lee Busst (left) and Ian Watson Gladwish (right)

65251619.caption: Wayne Busst and Ian Gladwish had both been Big Issue sellers
65251619.altText: Wayne Lee Busst (left) and Ian Watson Gladwish (right)

items.summary: Two men stabbed to death in front of shoppers in Birmingham city centre were Big Issue sellers, the publication confirms.
items.headline: Birmingham stabbings: Stab victims were Big Issue sellers
items.shortHeadline: Stab victims were Big Issue men

items.summary: Two men are stabbed to death in the busy shopping area of Birmingham city centre, with a man arrested a few minutes later.
items.headline: Birmingham city centre stabbings leave two men dead
items.shortHeadline: Two men killed in city stabbings

results.headline: Birmingham stabbings: Attacker 'knew Big Issue victims'
